results.name: Smallest integer s>n such that 1+2*s+3*s^2+...+n*s^{n-1} is prime.
comment: Conjecture: For each n=2,3,... there are infinitely many primes of the form 1+2*s+...+n*s^{n-1}, where s is a positive integer; moreover, we have a(n)<12*n^2.

This is related to the following conjecture of the author: The polynomials s_n(x)=sum_{k=0}^n(k+1)x^k (n=1,2,3,...) are all irreducible over the field of rational numbers; moreover, s_n(x) is reducible modulo every prime if and only if n has the form 8k(k+1), where k is a positive integer.
link: Zhi-Wei Sun and Charles R Greathouse IV, Table of n, a(n) for n = 2..1000 (first 450 terms from Sun)
example: a(20)=4500<12*20^2=4800 since 4500 is the least integer s>20 with 1+2*s+3*s^2+...+20*s^{19} prime.
results.author: _Zhi-Wei Sun_, Mar 24 2013
